Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2009 01:29PM revkat wrote: Everytime I read the title of this thread I am annoyed. Dr. Love did not say there is no need for LE risk reductions, she said that women will continue to push the limits. And we may discover that some of what we have been told actually does reduce risk, and some of it is not needed. And because it would be really hard to fill a study with people willing to intentionally be exposed to the risk of LE, new information may well come because of people pushing the current limits. I was following all the rules and I developed LE very shortly after radiation with no obvious trigger. I think it has way more to do with our underlying lymph system than what we do with our arms. HOWEVER, once you have LE and know that your system is compromised it makes a lot of sense to avoid anything that could lead to cellulitis and to manage the swelling as best you can. I found the study about weightlifting empowering. I hated the thought that I wasn't supposed to lift anything more than 5 lbs for the rest of my life. I couldn't find a specialized trainer (admittedly I didn't look too hard) but I took in the method section of the study and talked with a trainer at my gym and we put together a slow, gentle program. I wear my sleeve and I monitor my swelling and other symptoms. On days I lift I make sure to wear my jovi pak at night. I feel much better knowing that picking up a baby is something that I can do, not something that will hurt my arm. I really wonder if you can "ward off" LE, or if you are going to get it you just will no matter what. But there is a big difference between trying to prevent it and dealing with it once you have it. And a difference between people with mild and moderate and severe LE. So, once again on this BC journey we have to work out what works for each of us.

Posts.Content: May 13, 2009 07:54PM revkat wrote: If your tumor was estrogen positive and Her2 negative and you are postmenapausal, the Oncotype DX test will give you good information regarding the effectiveness of chemo for your cancer. If you are Her2 positive you will want herceptin and that is currently always given with some kind of chemo. If you are estrogen negative you will need chemo because hormonal treatments are not available to you as an alternative way to control any cancer cells that have escaped from the tumor. If you are premenapausal the Oncotype could still be helpful, but the company that makes it doesn't stand behind it yet since not enough research has been done, and your insurance company may not pay for it ($3000). Also, in the US it would be a rare thing (though I think there is someone on these boards who was this rare occurrence) for an oncologist to suggest skipping chemo if the cancer had spread to your lymph nodes.

Posts.Content: revkat wrote: I was referred by my PT to a medical supply place for a custom sleeve and not custom glove. First, I had to make an appointment to be measured. Waited a week for that. Was measured. Waited 3 weeks for the sleeve to arrive. Went in to try it on. It was a different fitter (the first one seemed like an air head, the second one seemed to know what she was doing.) She wondered aloud why I had been given a Medi since most people get Juzo or Jobst, then remembered that the first fitter only knows how to do Medi measurements. With much tugging we get the sleeve on. It only reaches to my mid-upper arm. And the wrist goes down below my wrist bones so it binds when I move my hand. (The glove fits, but of course to have it be the same color as the sleeve would be too much to ask). So she re-measures the length of my arm. Below the elbow it's just off by .5cm, but above the elbow it is off by 3cm. She say she will talk to the sales rep about ordering me one that fits better. Then I get a call that the sales rep has said she should remeasure the circumference as well as length so we make an appointment for that. Another week. I go in. The sales rep and both fitters are there. To get the sleeve on requires a donning device and everyone pushing and pulling. The sales rep thinks it only looks about an inch too short. She suggests they wet it and try to stretch it to get the extra inch. I go home. Go back today to pick it up. No one was in the office but the secretary. She hands it to me and says "put it on". I point out that it took several people with rubber gloves and a donning device to get it on the day before, I'm probably not going to be able to do it myself. She calls fitter 1 (who evidently owns the place). He tells her where to find gloves but says I can't have a donning device. You can tell that the upper arm has been stretched because of the spaces between the sleeve and the silicone band and it sort of looks stretched out of shape. I get the damn thing on. It still does not reach to my axilla -- about an inch shy so on the outer arm it  maybe reaches 3/4 of the way up my upper arm. Not to mention that it is very uncomfortable at the wrist because it is too long. At this point I was close to losing it. I took off the sleeve and said "I need one that fits properly" and left. Every time I think about it I want to scream. I'm not sure what to do next. I'm not going to wear that sleeve. Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2009 10:12AM revkat wrote: I'm not going to touch the diet stuff, but I want to point out that this is an article about a study done with mice that looked at the mechanism for the spread of cancer. While the findings are very interesting, a lot more would have to be done to move to the point of clinical application in humans. This is the kind of basic research that needs to be done so that we know more about what is behind the growth of cancers, but imho to take this study and claim that the treatments that women are having causes their cancer to spread is really jumping the gun. And really, cancer research is constantly being done. You think your docs should tell you about every study done before they give you treatment? Part of what we pay them for is to sift through this stuff for what is clinically relevant (and, yes, some do a better job than others.)

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2010 04:11PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 05:53AM by revkat Just thought I'd update you all. The race (well, "race" is a bit of an overstatement, our aim is to finish, so maybe I should just call it an "event") is this weekend. I tried swimming both way and I just can't stand the feel of the sleeve in the water. At first with the swimming (when I was doing less than 1000 yds) I really noticed that it was good for my arm. Everything felt so much better after swimming. But then, when I up the yardage, I've had more problems. I've compensated by wearing my jovi pak more regularly. I am going to be wearing a sleevless wetsuit for this event. I've wondered if a full wetsuit, when the water is colder, would provide compression? Hmmm. I probably won't be finding out, because swimming has turned out to be my least favorite part of this. So I will have to don a sleeve over a damp arm, but I'm pretty good at sleeve doning. Just have to be careful not to slug myself in the jaw while pulling it on. It really has helped to have a new sleeve for the biking and running, although I hate getting a new sleeve all dirty (got some bike grease on one). I'm wrestling with biking gloves at the present. When I wear a biking glove over my glove my little finger tends to go numb(even though I'm wearing large gloves). If I don't wear a biking glove my palms, especially near the wrist, gets sore. I'm experimenting with putting some foam inside a stretched out glove, but that won't work for the triathlon. So, I'll probably just let the little finger go numb for this event. I like the biking the best and plan to continue with it after this so I'll keep tinkering. Running. I hated it the most at first, but seem to have turned a corner. Still, I don't know if I could do more than the 5k. My arms get tired and heavy if I let them hang down at all. Thanks for all the suggestions. I'll let you know how it goes. I'm ready for the training to be over, but I'm looking forward to the event itself. After all, everyone gets a medal!

Posts.Content: May 12, 2008 09:13AM revkat wrote: Hi, I'm just dropping by from the April thread. Wanted to add (for what it's worth) my experience with constipation was that it was fine to wait until the night after chemo to take the first stool softener. But I haven't had it as bad as many folks do. And with the nausea -- I was told the same thing about morning sickness (which I had a moderate amount of with 3 pregnancies) and motion sickness (which I have a lot of). But, I haven't had any nausea with chemo! I'm on zofran, before chem and then I take it every 8 hours without fail for the next 3 days. Everyone seems to respond to all these things a bit differently, so the first time around remember to write down what you take when and how you feel (you will forget by the time your next treatment comes around), then you can tweak things for round 2. In general though, most of us seem to discover that we should go ahead and take all those meds! You probably will only need them for the first week but it is always better to stay ahead for the se's than to try to catch up to them.

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2010 06:39PM revkat wrote: Hey Kate, Docs vary about scans at Stage 2b. It is not abnormal to only have labs and a chest x-ray, though some also do a bone scan and abdominal CT or some kind of MRI. If you are 3 years out with no symptoms of mets and your lab work is still looking good, just consider the radiation you didn't get with more scans as a good thing! It is normal not to have rads with less than 4 positive nodes if you have a mastectomy. With 1-3 positive nodes a lot would depend on the margins they got. If they were positive or very close, rads could be suggested. If the margins were good and clear it's less likely. Also, 3 years ago they seemed to be less aggressive about the rads with mastectomy. Leg pain and tamoxifen. Yep, it happens. The best thing is to move around, but if you can't do that could you do some of the stretching exercises they recommend for long plane flights? Like foot circles and seated legs lifts. Or seated bring your heels up to your seat as much as possible and then extend your leg? Will they really not let you stand and do a deep knee bend between calls? That sucks. On breaks can you walk around and stretch out a bit? Sounds like you are doing well!

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2008 10:39AM revkat wrote: Well, I finally registered after lurking for a month or so. I start 4 cycles of T/C today. And it's not an April Fool joke. Dang. Prior to surgery (lumpectomy) the doctor was thinking about 1cm, nodes looked clear clinically, grade was 1. I got adjusted to thinking surgery, rads, tamox, and out. But no, 2cm. grade 2, and that stupid sentinel node with a .8 tumor. I spent a good week reading every study I could find about chemo trying to figure a way out, but finally have accepted that there's no onco in North America that wouldn't recommend it. (Maybe in Europe, my onco acknowledges, but I'm not in Europe, am I?) So today it is. I've got 3 girls -- 20, 16, 13. The oldest is home on medical leave from her first real job because of chronic headaches, which stinks for her, but has been great for me. She's a real help. The middle is a senior and has to figure out college for next year -- this diagnosis has made staying close to home look attractive to her, but I want her to stretch her wings. The youngest is the sweetest 13 year old girl ever. (Takes after her dad that way, they are both so easy going and caring). My mom also lives with us, and she broke her hip two days before my surgery. She's doing well, but let me say, we sure didn't plan 08 to look like this! It's either anxiety or the steriods, but I am totally wired this morning. It will be good to just get it done! I hate having to do this, but am glad to have the option and folks to go through it with.

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2008 12:05AM - edited Apr 28, 2008 12:19AM by revkat I blame the weepiness on day 4-6 (depending on individual preference). And otter, don't worry to much about that index. It's so general that I don't see how it can be useful in indidivual cases. Sure, big is worse that small, fewer nodes are better, lower grade is better, but that leaves a whole lot out about the biology of your tumor and the effect your treatment has on it. (But looking at your diagnosis I get a Nottingham index of 3.2, isn't that supposed to be good?) There is an end to this, really. If you are doing dose dense, I don't know, but I still can promise, there is an end.

I thought I could work 2 out of 3 weeks, but it wasn't possible -- my employer is super flexible, so they are willing to take a bit of work from home and one out of 3 weeks, but otherwise I'd have to forget it. If your counts are low of course you feel lousy. You may feel better next round if they figure out how to keep your counts up. I have decided not to entertain thoughts about what I'm learning, or what meaning this all may have at this point. Right now it's just about one foot in front of the other, taking the next step. Be kind to yourself, don't measure by what someone else can do, rest when you need to. kat

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2011 03:18PM revkat wrote: It's been 3 years since diagnosis for me, and one of the things I have noted in following bc research is that different studies get different results. Patients want answers, and we want them now, but I can imagine that physicians who have been following the research for a decade of two have seen new ideas, based a one study, some and go. If I had it to do over, today, with what I know now, I would discuss the study that shows no overall survival benefit for axillary dissection in detail with my surgeon. If I did proceed with one, I would also want to discuss the LE prevention information that is out there, in particular the part about not beginning to stretch at all until healing is well underway (I thought I was supposed to get going with the exercises like the day after surgery). I do have mild LE but in my case I got attention right away and have learned techniques for managing it and have very few problems. My arm never has looked like the horror pictures posted (they showed us worse than that at an LE educational program that went with my treatment). Jane and Molly feel very strongly that no one should have axillary dissections and that no one should take Aromatase Inhibitors. That's their opinion. Each person facing these decisions needs to talk with their doctors, raise your doubts, listen to their reasoning, and make your own decision. I once asked my oncologist how she could stand her job, since there are so many unknowns in bc treatment and we are never absolutely sure it won't come back. She said, "that's why I treat other kinds of cancer too."! Oncologists know how much they don't know with this fricking disease, they would love for their to be a magic bullets, but until that day we slog on into the unknown with what we know.

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2008 11:26PM revkat wrote: Well, I saw that video too, and the PT left us alone to view it. But prior to that we had an educational session with the PT and one other woman where we could ask lots of questions. And then after viewing the video the PT spent quite a bit of time going over the massage with me. I never felt like she wasn't open to questions. I had at least 2 follow-up sessions, it's hard to remember now. I did have a horrible time getting my sleeve measured and ordered and delivered. But that was the company that Kaiser contracts with not KP itself. My impression was that I wasn't getting the care that some here have described where the PT actually does hands on massage of them and wraps their arm and teaching them about wrapping. I don't know if that is just because my LE was so mild, or if wrapping is not part of Kaiser's standard of care for LE. I know that Kaiser has a few PTs scattered about CA who are listed on the LE therapist website, and I've thought about emailing one of them to see if I could get a better picture of what Kaiser offers for LE patients. At any rate, I think you should follow up somehow. You could contact member services, or you could start by emailing the PT directly (if you register with the KP website you can email any of the medical personnel who treat you. We've always gotten prompt replies). Maybe you caught him/her on a bad day, maybe this therapist really doesn't know about LE and was just assigned to cover it, maybe it's just a bad match and you can request a different therapist. I don't know, but we've discovered with Kaiser that there often is another possiblity than the one presented, but we may have to dig for it.
